title: Canavan seeks US help to develop rare earths resources
text:
China controls 80 per cent

China, a US strategic competitor currently engaged in a trade war with Washington, controls at least 80 per cent of global trade in rare earths.

Critical minerals, including rare earths, lithium, copper and cobalt, are a vital part of the defence supply chain, being used in everything from weapons guidance systems to improving the durability of electronics used in the field. They are also components for wind turbines, electric vehicles, power tools and fridges.

The bilateral discussions build on talks between President Trump and Prime Minister Scott Morrison in Washington.

As well as seeking development capital from the US and other foreign allies, the Morrison government is exploring whether to deploy funds to early-stage projects from the export credit agency Export Finance Australia and the Northern Australia Infrastructure Facility.

Arafura Resources seeks backing

Arafura Resources managing director Gavin Lockyer said he had pressed the Morrison government for Australia and the US to provide concessional government loans to help fund its planned $1.1 billion rare earths project located near Alice Springs.

"Most of these critical minerals projects require major capital but are being developed by small to medium sized miners," Mr Lockyer said.

Advertisement

"Governments can become an enabler by recognising it as a strategic project to send a confidence signal to private equity and debt investors."

A US Studies Centre report on rare earths by David Uren questions whether the government should use taxpayer money to develop rare earths.

"Australia has at least half a dozen rare earth projects ready for development but needing commitments from potential customers and financiers," Mr Uren noted.

"However, it would have to go into any such commitment with its eyes open to the possibility of losses to the taxpayer – rare earths have often been in oversupply with poor prices."

ASX-listed Lynas, the biggest supplier of rare earths outside China, is edging closer to making a call on building a first-stage processing plant next door to BHP’s Nickel West operations outside Kalgoorlie in Western Australia.

Arafura's Neodymium-Praseodymium rich deposit is targeting non-Chinese export markets and the company has held talks with the US Defence Department, according to the US Studies Centre report. Chinese investors also have a minority stake in the firm and it has a non-binding offtake agreement with a Chinese permanent magnet maker.

Arafura's Mr Lockyer said the project was going well since raising more than $20 million in July to progress engineering work, after earlier passing a feasibility study and environmental approvals.

If project finance is forthcoming, he said soil could be turned by late 2020 and producing by around 2023.

Mr Morrison said on Wednesday Australia was co-operating on international supply chains for critical minerals and rare earths with countries including the US, Japan, India and the Netherlands.

Mr Morrison will meet Mr Ross this week on his visit to Canberra and Sydney.
description: President Donald Trump's commerce secretary Wilbur Ross has discussed mining projects critical to national security with Australia's resources minister.
